intro: Nissolia chacoensis, commonly known as the Chacoan nissolia, is a shrub native to the dry forests of South America, particularly in Paraguay and Argentina. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes over 13,000 species of flowering plants. The plant is characterized by its small, elliptical leaves and clusters of white or pale yellow flowers. It thrives in arid and semi-arid conditions, showcasing adaptations to drought through its succulent stems and reduced leaf surface. The fruit is a small, dry capsule that disperses seeds through wind or animal activity.
